| A human werejackal:* has [a head, a couple of arms, and a torso](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid").

* can pick up weapons and food.

* [regenerates HP quickly](/wiki/Regeneration "Regeneration").
* is [poisonous](/wiki/Poisonous "Poisonous") to eat.
* is [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivore "Carnivore").

| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   | [monst.c#line212](/wiki/Monst.c#line212 "Monst.c")                      |

A **werejackal**, @ / d, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. The werejackal is an [omnivorous](/wiki/Omnivorous "Omnivorous") [human](/wiki/Human_\(monster_attribute\) "Human (monster attribute)") [werecreature](/wiki/Werecreature "Werecreature") that can shift between [human](/wiki/Human_or_elf "Human or elf") and [canine](/wiki/Canine "Canine") form - in both forms, they possess enhanced [regeneration](/wiki/Regeneration "Regeneration") and can be seen via [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"). In human form, werejackals will seek out and pick up items.

A werejackal in human form has a weapon attack, and in [jackal](/wiki/Jackal "Jackal") form it has a bite that can cause [lycanthropy](/wiki/Lycanthropy "Lycanthropy") in the [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero"), along with the ability to summon other jackals and canines on nearby squares when in melee range. Werejackals possess [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") and [drain resistance](/wiki/Drain_resistance "Drain resistance"), and are weak to [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver").

A werejackal [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") is [poisonous](/wiki/Poisonous "Poisonous") to eat, and a hero eating a werejackal corpse or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") will be given lycanthropy.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 GruntHack](#GruntHack)
  - [6.3 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [6.4 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [6.5 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly-generated werejackals are always created hostile and in human form. They are not a valid form for normal [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph").

A werejackal summoning help has a 6⁄7 chance of generating a hostile jackal, a 2⁄21 chance of generating a hostile [coyote](/wiki/Coyote "Coyote"), and a 1⁄21 chance of generating a hostile [fox](/wiki/Fox "Fox") on each applicable square[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) - characters that get lycanthropy from a werejackal can summon the above monsters as pets by using the [#monster](/wiki/Monster_\(command\) "Monster (command)") [extended command](/wiki/Extended_command "Extended command"), which costs 10 [power](/wiki/Power "Power").

## Strategy

- *Main article: [Lycanthropy](/wiki/Lycanthropy "Lycanthropy")*

Werejackals are often the first type of lycanthrope a character can encounter - they are somewhat weak, with both forms having poor [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") and an unimpressive [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)") of 10, but their regeneration makes them somewhat tricky to kill if an early character cannot damage them consistently. Contracting lycanthropy from one will eventually cause a character to shift to a much weaker jackal form, shrink out of their armor and drop most of their inventory unless cured. When encountering werejackals, take them out as quickly as possible: Being pinned on all sides, even by the weaker canines they summon, can lead to death fairly quickly unless you can [engrave](/wiki/Engrave "Engrave") [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth").

A character that finds a silver weapon early on will want to keep it on hand until they can reliably take out werecreatures with little trouble, since the silver damage alone can dispatch them quickly, even with a restricted weapon skill. [Pets](/wiki/Pets "Pets") can help deal with wererats, since they cannot catch lycanthropy and werecreatures only summon help while attacking you in animal form. Pulling a werejackal into a hallway is also viable: summoning in hallways makes it easier for a character to be completely surrounded, but can significantly limit the amount of monsters they have to fight simultaneously.

If possible, avoid engaging werejackals and other lycanthropes in melee while they are in animal form, unless you can cure any infections - [eating](/wiki/Eating "Eating") [sprigs of wolfsbane](/wiki/Sprigs_of_wolfsbane "Sprigs of wolfsbane") or [quaffing](/wiki/Quaff "Quaff") [holy water](/wiki/Holy_water "Holy water") will cure lycanthropy, as will successful [prayer](/wiki/Prayer "Prayer"). A [ring of protection from shape changers](/wiki/Ring_of_protection_from_shape_changers "Ring of protection from shape changers") will outright prevent them from summoning monsters or infecting you.

## History

The werejackal first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"). From this version to [NetHack 3.0.10](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.10 "NetHack 3.0.10"), their animal forms are referred to as **jackalweres** - a monster known as the jackalwere also appears in [SLASH 6](/wiki/SLASH_6 "SLASH 6").

The ability of werejackals to summon allied coyotes and foxes is introduced in [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0"). In [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") and previous versions, including some variants based on those versions, werejackals summoning help will only generate hostile jackals on each applicable square.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Therianthropy](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Therianthropy "wikipedia:Therianthropy")***

The concept of humans shapeshifting into animals has been a common concept in folklore among various human eras and cultures, while ["therianthropy"](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Therianthropy "wikipedia:Therianthropy") and related terms as a means of describing specific forms of human-animal shapeshifting have been in use since the early 20th century.

Werejackals are a much less common form of therianthrope in fantasy media, appearing much more rarely compared to mainstays such as [werewolves](/wiki/Werewolves "Werewolves") and even [wererats](/wiki/Wererat "Wererat") - they do appear alongside them and other therianthropes in *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, with their debut being much later in comparison. Werejackals are first mentioned in the 1994 *Monstrous Compendium* titled "Ravenloft Appendix III: Creatures of Darkness". More common in the franchise is their "opposite" number, the jackalwere: jackals that are able to assume the form of a human, and are innately linked to a trickster deity. This meant that jackalweres were not only natural-born deceivers, but that any attempt to be truthful would cause one literal pain.

Jackalweres are not especially strong in humanoid form, which prevents them from using their claws as effective weapons and limits them to biting and using whatever weapons they can find - this was rarely a problem, considering that like most other lycanthropes they were immune to weaponry that was not magic, silvered or cold iron. Jackalweres still possess a dangerous gaze ability that is capable of lulling unsuspecting victims into a ten-minute-long trance, though it had several major limitations: for example, the gaze only worked on beings that were in a state of calm, and could not affect other jackalweres or any charm-resistant beings. Even so, jackalweres are still treacherous and should be treated with caution, as they often use their humanoid forms to appear outwardly helplessness, lowering their victim's guard before using their gaze or otherwise attacking.

## Messages

- You hear a jackal howling at the moon.

  A werejackal shifted into animal form on the current level.

## Variants

Variants based on NetHack 3.4.3 and previous versions may not include the ability for werejackals to summon other canines, as in later versions.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), werejackals can only summon other jackals, but [hit monsters as +1 weapons](/wiki/Hits_creatures_as_%2Bx_weapon "Hits creatures as +x weapon"). Like other polymorphed monsters, they can revert to human form if they are killed in animal form, making them much more dangerous; they also have a chance of undergoing [system shock](/wiki/System_shock "System shock"), typically when killed in human form.

Werejackals may appear among the @ generated within the [Lawful Quest](/wiki/Lawful_Quest "Lawful Quest")'s Chamber of Junk.

All of the above also applies to [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM").

### GruntHack

In [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), werejackals can only summon other jackals, and they and other lycanthropes are also generated as [racial monsters](/wiki/Racial_monster "Racial monster").

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), werejackals can summon other canines, with the ability to generate foxes and coyotes as in vanilla *NetHack*.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), werejackals can only summon other jackals, and are the only vanilla werecreature that is not buffed in dNetHack. They also do not generate randomly, and can only be summoned by [anubites](/wiki/Anubite "Anubite"): the anubite is a much stronger type of werejackal that can take the form of an [anuban jackal](/wiki/Anuban_jackal "Anuban jackal"), and can confer werejackal lycanthropy by biting a character in jackal form.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), werejackals can only summon other jackals.

As in SLASH'EM, werejackals may appear among the @ generated within the Lawful Quest's Chamber of Junk.

## Encyclopedia entry

- *See the [encyclopedia entry for werecreature](/wiki/Werecreature#Encyclopedia_entry "Werecreature").*

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/were.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 148](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/were.c#L148)

Reference monst.c#line212

A werejackal, @ / d, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. The werejackal is an omnivorous human werecreature that can shift between human and canine form - in both forms, they possess enhanced regeneration and can be seen via infravision. In human form, werejackals will seek out and pick up items.

A werejackal in human form has a weapon attack, and in jackal form it has a bite that can cause lycanthropy in the hero, along with the ability to summon other jackals and canines on nearby squares when in melee range. Werejackals possess poison resistance and drain resistance, and are weak to silver.

A werejackal corpse is poisonous to eat, and a hero eating a werejackal corpse or tin will be given lycanthropy.

Contents

  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Messages
  • 6 Variants
    • 6.1 SLASH'EM
    • 6.2 GruntHack

    • 6.5 Hack'EM
  • 7 Encyclopedia entry
  • 8 References

Generation

Randomly-generated werejackals are always created hostile and in human form. They are not a valid form for normal polymorph.

A werejackal summoning help has a 6⁄7 chance of generating a hostile jackal, a 2⁄21 chance of generating a hostile coyote, and a 1⁄21 chance of generating a hostile fox on each applicable square[1] - characters that get lycanthropy from a werejackal can summon the above monsters as pets by using the #monster extended command, which costs 10 power.

Strategy

Main article: Lycanthropy

Werejackals are often the first type of lycanthrope a character can encounter - they are somewhat weak, with both forms having poor AC and an unimpressive MR score of 10, but their regeneration makes them somewhat tricky to kill if an early character cannot damage them consistently. Contracting lycanthropy from one will eventually cause a character to shift to a much weaker jackal form, shrink out of their armor and drop most of their inventory unless cured. When encountering werejackals, take them out as quickly as possible: Being pinned on all sides, even by the weaker canines they summon, can lead to death fairly quickly unless you can engrave Elbereth.

A character that finds a silver weapon early on will want to keep it on hand until they can reliably take out werecreatures with little trouble, since the silver damage alone can dispatch them quickly, even with a restricted weapon skill. Pets can help deal with wererats, since they cannot catch lycanthropy and werecreatures only summon help while attacking you in animal form. Pulling a werejackal into a hallway is also viable: summoning in hallways makes it easier for a character to be completely surrounded, but can significantly limit the amount of monsters they have to fight simultaneously.

If possible, avoid engaging werejackals and other lycanthropes in melee while they are in animal form, unless you can cure any infections - eating sprigs of wolfsbane or quaffing holy water will cure lycanthropy, as will successful prayer. A ring of protection from shape changers will outright prevent them from summoning monsters or infecting you.

History

The werejackal first appears in NetHack 3.0.0. From this version to NetHack 3.0.10, their animal forms are referred to as jackalweres - a monster known as the jackalwere also appears in SLASH 6.

The ability of werejackals to summon allied coyotes and foxes is introduced in NetHack 3.6.0. In NetHack 3.4.3 and previous versions, including some variants based on those versions, werejackals summoning help will only generate hostile jackals on each applicable square.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Therianthropy

The concept of humans shapeshifting into animals has been a common concept in folklore among various human eras and cultures, while "therianthropy" and related terms as a means of describing specific forms of human-animal shapeshifting have been in use since the early 20th century.

Werejackals are a much less common form of therianthrope in fantasy media, appearing much more rarely compared to mainstays such as werewolves and even wererats - they do appear alongside them and other therianthropes in Dungeons & Dragons, with their debut being much later in comparison. Werejackals are first mentioned in the 1994 Monstrous Compendium titled "Ravenloft Appendix III: Creatures of Darkness". More common in the franchise is their "opposite" number, the jackalwere: jackals that are able to assume the form of a human, and are innately linked to a trickster deity. This meant that jackalweres were not only natural-born deceivers, but that any attempt to be truthful would cause one literal pain.

Jackalweres are not especially strong in humanoid form, which prevents them from using their claws as effective weapons and limits them to biting and using whatever weapons they can find - this was rarely a problem, considering that like most other lycanthropes they were immune to weaponry that was not magic, silvered or cold iron. Jackalweres still possess a dangerous gaze ability that is capable of lulling unsuspecting victims into a ten-minute-long trance, though it had several major limitations: for example, the gaze only worked on beings that were in a state of calm, and could not affect other jackalweres or any charm-resistant beings. Even so, jackalweres are still treacherous and should be treated with caution, as they often use their humanoid forms to appear outwardly helplessness, lowering their victim's guard before using their gaze or otherwise attacking.

A werejackal shifted into animal form on the current level.

Variants

Variants based on NetHack 3.4.3 and previous versions may not include the ability for werejackals to summon other canines, as in later versions.

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, werejackals can only summon other jackals, but hit monsters as +1 weapons. Like other polymorphed monsters, they can revert to human form if they are killed in animal form, making them much more dangerous; they also have a chance of undergoing system shock, typically when killed in human form.

Werejackals may appear among the @ generated within the Lawful Quest's Chamber of Junk.

All of the above also applies to SlashTHEM.

GruntHack

In GruntHack, werejackals can only summon other jackals, and they and other lycanthropes are also generated as racial monsters.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, werejackals can summon other canines, with the ability to generate foxes and coyotes as in vanilla NetHack.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, notdNetHack and notnotdNetHack, werejackals can only summon other jackals, and are the only vanilla werecreature that is not buffed in dNetHack. They also do not generate randomly, and can only be summoned by anubites: the anubite is a much stronger type of werejackal that can take the form of an anuban jackal, and can confer werejackal lycanthropy by biting a character in jackal form.

Hack'EM

In Hack'EM, werejackals can only summon other jackals.

As in SLASH'EM, werejackals may appear among the @ generated within the Lawful Quest's Chamber of Junk.

Encyclopedia entry

See the encyclopedia entry for werecreature.

A '''werejackal''', {{monsym|werejackal}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. The werejackal is an [[omnivorous]] [[Human (monster attribute)|human]] [[werecreature]] that can shift between [[Human or elf|human]] and [[canine]] form - in both forms, they possess enhanced [[regeneration]] and can be seen via [[infravision]]. In human form, werejackals will seek out and pick up items.

A werejackal in human form has a weapon attack, and in [[jackal]] form it has a bite that can cause [[lycanthropy]] in the [[hero]], along with the ability to summon other jackals and canines on nearby squares when in melee range. Werejackals possess [[poison resistance]] and [[drain resistance]], and are weak to [[silver]].

A werejackal [[corpse]] is [[poisonous]] to eat, and a hero eating a werejackal corpse or [[tin]] will be given lycanthropy.

==Generation==
Randomly-generated werejackals are always created hostile and in human form. They are not a valid form for normal [[polymorph]].

A werejackal summoning help has a {{frac|6|7}} chance of generating a hostile jackal, a {{frac|2|21}} chance of generating a hostile [[coyote]], and a {{frac|21}} chance of generating a hostile [[fox]] on each applicable square{{refsrc|src/were.c|148|nethack=3.6.7}} - characters that get lycanthropy from a werejackal can summon the above monsters as pets by using the [[Monster (command)|#monster]] [[extended command]], which costs 10 [[power]].

==Strategy==
{{main|Lycanthropy}}
Werejackals are often the first type of lycanthrope a character can encounter - they are somewhat weak, with both forms having poor [[AC]] and an unimpressive [[Magic resistance (monster)|MR score]] of 10, but their regeneration makes them somewhat tricky to kill if an early character cannot damage them consistently. Contracting lycanthropy from one will eventually cause a character to shift to a much weaker jackal form, shrink out of their armor and drop most of their inventory unless cured. When encountering werejackals, take them out as quickly as possible: Being pinned on all sides, even by the weaker canines they summon, can lead to death fairly quickly unless you can [[engrave]] [[Elbereth]].

A character that finds a silver weapon early on will want to keep it on hand until they can reliably take out werecreatures with little trouble, since the silver damage alone can dispatch them quickly, even with a restricted weapon skill. [[Pets]] can help deal with wererats, since they cannot catch lycanthropy and werecreatures only summon help while attacking you in animal form. Pulling a werejackal into a hallway is also viable: summoning in hallways makes it easier for a character to be completely surrounded, but can significantly limit the amount of monsters they have to fight simultaneously.

If possible, avoid engaging werejackals and other lycanthropes in melee while they are in animal form, unless you can cure any infections - [[eating]] [[sprigs of wolfsbane]] or [[quaff]]ing [[holy water]] will cure lycanthropy, as will successful [[prayer]]. A [[ring of protection from shape changers]] will outright prevent them from summoning monsters or infecting you.

==History==
The werejackal first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]]. From this version to [[NetHack 3.0.10]], their animal forms are referred to as '''jackalweres''' - a monster known as the jackalwere also appears in [[SLASH 6]].

The ability of werejackals to summon allied coyotes and foxes is introduced in [[NetHack 3.6.0]]. In [[NetHack 3.4.3]] and previous versions, including some variants based on those versions, werejackals summoning help will only generate hostile jackals on each applicable square.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Therianthropy}}
The concept of humans shapeshifting into animals has been a common concept in folklore among various human eras and cultures, while [[wikipedia:Therianthropy|"therianthropy"]] and related terms as a means of describing specific forms of human-animal shapeshifting have been in use since the early 20th century.

Werejackals are a much less common form of therianthrope in fantasy media, appearing much more rarely compared to mainstays such as [[werewolves]] and even [[wererat]]s - they do appear alongside them and other therianthropes in ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'', with their debut being much later in comparison. Werejackals are first mentioned in the 1994 ''Monstrous Compendium'' titled "Ravenloft Appendix III: Creatures of Darkness". More common in the franchise is their "opposite" number, the jackalwere: jackals that are able to assume the form of a human, and are innately linked to a trickster deity. This meant that jackalweres were not only natural-born deceivers, but that any attempt to be truthful would cause one literal pain.

Jackalweres are not especially strong in humanoid form, which prevents them from using their claws as effective weapons and limits them to biting and using whatever weapons they can find - this was rarely a problem, considering that like most other lycanthropes they were immune to weaponry that was not magic, silvered or cold iron. Jackalweres still possess a dangerous gaze ability that is capable of lulling unsuspecting victims into a ten-minute-long trance, though it had several major limitations: for example, the gaze only worked on beings that were in a state of calm, and could not affect other jackalweres or any charm-resistant beings. Even so, jackalweres are still treacherous and should be treated with caution, as they often use their humanoid forms to appear outwardly helplessness, lowering their victim's guard before using their gaze or otherwise attacking.

==Messages==
{{message|You hear a jackal howling at the moon.|A werejackal shifted into animal form on the current level.}}

==Variants==
Variants based on NetHack 3.4.3 and previous versions may not include the ability for werejackals to summon other canines, as in later versions.

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], werejackals can only summon other jackals, but [[Hits creatures as +x weapon|hit monsters as +1 weapons]]. Like other polymorphed monsters, they can revert to human form if they are killed in animal form, making them much more dangerous; they also have a chance of undergoing [[system shock]], typically when killed in human form.

Werejackals may appear among the {{white|@}} generated within the [[Lawful Quest]]'s Chamber of Junk.

All of the above also applies to [[SlashTHEM]].

===GruntHack===
In [[GruntHack]], werejackals can only summon other jackals, and they and other lycanthropes are also generated as [[racial monster]]s.

===UnNetHack===
In [[UnNetHack]], werejackals can summon other canines, with the ability to generate foxes and coyotes as in vanilla ''NetHack''.

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]], werejackals can only summon other jackals, and are the only vanilla werecreature that is not buffed in dNetHack. They also do not generate randomly, and can only be summoned by [[anubite]]s: the anubite is a much stronger type of werejackal that can take the form of an [[anuban jackal]], and can confer werejackal lycanthropy by biting a character in jackal form.

===Hack'EM===
In [[Hack'EM]], werejackals can only summon other jackals.

As in SLASH'EM, werejackals may appear among the {{white|@}} generated within the Lawful Quest's Chamber of Junk.
